column4: I would like to run a unix command when the computer starts, but not as root, as a user. How would I do that?
System > Preferences > Startup Applications
Tried that, but gnome doesn't start on boot.
So, what do you get on boot?
I can SSH in. That's what I"m doing.
Hmmm. You want it to run every time or just once?
Every time on boot.
Have you checked up on adding your commands at the end of ~/.bashrc?
If I add it to .bashrc, wouldn't I have to log in with SSH before the command is run?
This might be easier: I want to start vncserver on boot.
Ahh. So that's what you want to do. Hmmm. I can't think of anything else but adding it to /etc/init.rcXd.
But then again, that would execute the process as root.
And vncserver needs to be started as the user, right?
Could I write a script that did like 'su fxfitz; vncserver'??
That could work I think. I'm checking up on if vncserver really needs to be run by the user.
I have vncserver installed on my desktop too so I'm trying to find out.
Where did you get the impression that vncserver should be run as user? Any documentation / link?
Well, all of the server information is stored in ~/.vnc/ so I figured it was user-specific.
My NXServer starts up via /etc/rc[2,3,5]d
NXServer?
I use NX Machine for remote desktop access: http://www.nomachine.com/download.php
I think it's the same as vncserver, but it's what we used at school and it's relatively painless to install.
I think su user -c "command" could work.
Awesome! I'll try that! Thanks! :-D
